context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: In Face Of Islamophobia, This Group Hosts ‘Meet A Muslim’ Events In Kansas
context_meta.summary: After President Donald Trump’s election and a corresponding spike in anti-Muslim hate crimes, one small group in the Kansas City area started organizing monthly “Meet a Muslim” events ― an effort to show community members who Muslims really are in real life, as opposed to the negative stereotypesthey might seein the news. The events were an idea from the nonprofit Crescent Peace Society, which has been seeking to raise awareness and improve understanding of Muslim cultures through interfaith events and dialogue since its founding in 1996. The volunteer-run group was started by a handful of Muslim parents after the Oklahoma City bombing, when some of their kids were afraid to return to school because classmates said they were responsible for the attack.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: How This Native Educator Is Keeping A Tribal Language Alive
context_meta.summary: On the Omaha Native American reservation in northeastern Nebraska, one educator is working hard to keep the tribal language alive by helping kids to learn it in school. Vida Woodhull Stabler is the director of the Omaha (or “Umonhon” in the tribe’s language) culture center at Umonhon Nation Public Schools in Macy, Nebraska. Alongside other elders in the community, she has helped to developed a curriculum and lesson plans for Umonhon language classes, as well as other ways to infuse students’ day-to-day school experience with culturally relevant learnings, such as tribal songs and dance.

Visibility is a theme Kleeb keeps coming back to ― whether its a booth at the state fair, a pamphlet-wielding volunteer at a livestock auction house, or on the ballot.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: In Face Of Islamophobia, This Group Hosts ‘Meet A Muslim’ Events In Kansas
context_meta.summary: After President Donald Trump’s election and a corresponding spike in anti-Muslim hate crimes, one small group in the Kansas City area started organizing monthly “Meet a Muslim” events ― an effort to show community members who Muslims really are in real life, as opposed to the negative stereotypesthey might seein the news. The events were an idea from the nonprofit Crescent Peace Society, which has been seeking to raise awareness and improve understanding of Muslim cultures through interfaith events and dialogue since its founding in 1996. The volunteer-run group was started by a handful of Muslim parents after the Oklahoma City bombing, when some of their kids were afraid to return to school because classmates said they were responsible for the attack.

text: My 22-year-old son does not have autism, but he has ADD and also has a learning disability, so he is in about the same situation as these young adults are. It has been a tough road, but getting out of high school was a virtual godsend to my son. They had no idea what to do with him, because he is not autistic nor does he have an obvious impediment to learning, so they put him here, they put him there, and nothing worked. Out on his own, he started to do things on his own. We got him into a program specifically for young adults with such problems, and he holds down a job. He still is socially inactive, but he is in another program that we hope helps him to be more social. He has no real friends, but we hope that this is simply another mountain that he has to conquer, and we really believe that he will. Public schools are not equipped to handle people like this, even though we so want them to be. I wish there had been some alternative to his schooling, but there wasn't. I have found my son to be smart, quite literate and yes, just discovering the world he lives in. I know that he is going to make it, but the road is a long one. He has a great support system, thank goodness, so he will be a success, on his own terms.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Two Mothers Open Up About What Happens When Kids With Autism Grow Up
context_meta.summary: People today are very aware of the challenges of raising a child with autism. From job opportunities to housing to social interactions, there are many aspects to worry about. Elaine Hall and Sue Patton know this all too well. Sue lives in a small town in Indiana called Pendleton.

text: I have 2 adult children with Autism, ages 22 and 25, that I refuse to place in a care facility; I've worked in homes early in my life fighting the injustices I witnessed and to this day continue to hear horror stories. Here in southeast North Carolina "services" are just about impossible to come by, let alone any kind of support. Having been forced out of our home by an abusive spouse we are now homeless (living in a hotel). Yes, I contacted local agencies; no, help is not available- lack of resources, no funding, calls not returned, etc. I know I'm not alone in this situation, what are we to do??

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: How This Native Educator Is Keeping A Tribal Language Alive
context_meta.summary: On the Omaha Native American reservation in northeastern Nebraska, one educator is working hard to keep the tribal language alive by helping kids to learn it in school. Vida Woodhull Stabler is the director of the Omaha (or “Umonhon” in the tribe’s language) culture center at Umonhon Nation Public Schools in Macy, Nebraska. Alongside other elders in the community, she has helped to developed a curriculum and lesson plans for Umonhon language classes, as well as other ways to infuse students’ day-to-day school experience with culturally relevant learnings, such as tribal songs and dance.

text: I think it us wonderful to teach them their native language.  They should be proud of their history and learning to speak a native tongue is something to be proud of.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Nebraska’s Nonpartisan, Unicameral Legislature Is A Model Of Deliberative Democracy
context_meta.summary: The Nebraska state legislature, which meets in Lincoln, is the only unicameral state legislature in the US and was specifically designed in the 1930s with multiple features to foster deliberative democracy by enhancing transparency and downplaying party politics.
